intro: Alnus incana f. hirsuta, commonly known as the hairy alder, is a variant of the alder tree characterized by its hairy foliage and bark. It is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. The plant belongs to the Betulaceae family, which includes birches and hazels, and is known for its ability to thrive in moist, well-drained soils. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and have a serrated margin, while its catkins are typically male and female. This species is often used in ecological restoration due to its nitrogen-fixing capabilities and adaptability to various environmental conditions.
